Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Modeling, Analysis, and Code Design for Portable Wireless Device Transmitters Subject to an Electromagnetic Exposure Constraint

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Portable wireless devices sold around the world number in the billions, and
they are used daily because of their ability to provide connectivity by
integrating processing power, touch screens, cameras, and motion sensors
with multiple radios, many of which can run simultaneously. Portable
wireless devices used in close proximity to the human body have transmitter
power constraints that are dictated largely by regulatory limits on a form
of electromagnetic exposure called ``specific absorption rate'' (SAR).
SAR, measured in Watts per kilogram, is a measure of the rate of
electromagnetic energy absorption by the body. Many portable wireless
devices sold today operate near the accepted human SAR limit. This
research examines how multiple transmitters on a portable wireless device
can be modeled, analyzed, and used while subject to a SAR constraint. The
work looks at how to model the constraint, and how to realize the
reliability and high data-rate advantages of multiple antennas subject to
the constraint.

Because portable devices are generally small, transmitters will be
physically close to one another and couple electromagnetically. Hence, the
research requires a blended effort in three distinct areas: (i)
electromagnetics and near-field exposure modeling with multiple
transmitters, (ii) wireless communication system far-field
information-theoretic performance evaluation with a near-field SAR
constraint, (iii) the design of SAR codes for optimum performance. Code
performance will be determined by simulation and by laboratory evaluation
with microwave equipment for near-field SAR and far-field error-rate
measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Portable wireless devices used in close proximity to the human body have transmitter power constraints that are largely dictated by regulatory limits on electromagnetic exposure and absorption (EA), typically set in terms of specific absorption rate (SAR) or temperature gradients. SAR, measured in Watts per kilogram, is a measure of the rate of electromagnetic energy absorption by the body. Many portable wireless devices sold today operate near the accepted human SAR limit. This project examined how multiple transmitters on a portable wireless device can be modeled, analyzed, and used while subject to a SAR constraint as well as a skin-temperature change limit.

With the fast increase of portable and wearable devices, the impacts on human health caused by the electromagnetic radiation have aroused close attention from the public. With multiple transmitting antennas present in modern portable devices, the net exposure effect can be either constructive or destructive, depending on the relative location, orientation, and excitation of the antennas.

One major research goal was to model, quantify, and calculate the EA measures such as SAR in human tissue under multi-antenna transmission. Such a model permits the fast and accurate estimation, prediction, and calculation of the electromagnetic absorption and can be integrated easily into other design and optimization of signals calculated specifically to mitigate EA.  Thus, the transmitter is "aware" of the EA effects of the transmitted signal, allowing the device to create signals that are EA compliant as part of their signal processing design.

Another major goal was to simplify the testing and verification of multi-antenna devices as being compliant to EA safety standards. As the number of antennas grows, the total number of possible transmitted signals generally grows, as much as exponentially, and therefore the time and cost burden of testing the devices grows proportionally. Methods to simplify and reduce this burden are of great interest since devices with large numbers of transmitting antennas are being anticipated for 4G and 5G wireless systems.

Among the successes of the work includes "beamforming" techniques that are aware of the human EA implications of the beams that are created, and thus seek to mitigate the EA, while simultaneously communicating with the intended receiver.  Beamforming is expected to be an increasingly popular technique for 5G systems, since it is useful for focusing electromagnetic energy at an intended receiver.  The techniques designed during our study can be directly applied to any portable wireless device that has beamforming as part of its transmission, helping to eliminate the worry of sending electromagnetic beams to be absorbed by a person rather than to the intended receiver.

Another success includes a technique that determines EA compliance of a portable wireless device whose time and complexity grows only linearly (proportionally) with the number of transmitter antennas.  This is in contrast to the number of possible transmitted signals, which can grow exponentially with the number of antennas.  This linear technique can be used by test houses, especially for devices that intend to use beamforming as part of their transmissions schemes.  In an example, the technique reduced the number of measurements needed to determine compliance from approximately two million to forty-four.

Finally, another successful outcome includes simple models based on Fourier analysis and quadratic modeling of the EA as a function of the phase between transmitting antennas.  Such a model enables the designers of the transmitter as well as the device itself predict the EA as a function of the signal it is transmitting, thus purposely avoiding signals that have high EA.  The models are especially simple and easily constructed, and work for any number of transmitting antennas.

Among the broader impacts addressed by this project includes the combining of various science and technical disciplines needed to advance work in this topic.  Students had to be versed in electromagnetic principles, basic biological principles, and communication and signal processing principles.  Hence, many students were attracted to the interdisciplinary nature of the study.  Several conference and journal papers were published, or are in the process of being published, and at least one patent application was generated during the course of the work.  Hence, the results were widely disseminated to the public throughout the project.
